Change has been successfully merged by Alex Wilson
Is there a canonical reference for x.509 Certificates and Identities (and the properties they specify) that we could link to here?

There's the X509 RFC -- https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280
But it's not exactly succinct or easily navigable if you don't want to basically implement the whole thing yourself And the extensions are scattered around a bunch of other RFCs

There's some information on the "Security certificate" Wikipedia page.  Up to you if you think that's useful.  It might be nice for developers less familiar with these details (including me), but it's a fine line between useful pointers and pointing out what should be obvious.
Is there a reason that this factory method isn't hanging off 'Certificate' like the others?

So.. in the case of the other classes in sshpk, they have parseX() methods in the root namespace, because it's their only factory method. I guess we have two options here if we want to change this: either we make Certificate the same as the others and move all its factory methods to the root, or we make Certificate different to the others and don't put any of its factory methods in the root. Any opinion?
Not really.  Either way seems okay.
Elsewhere, "key" is a public key.  Maybe name this one "privateKey" to be more explicit?  (I know that's implied by the fact that you're going to be signing the new certificate.)

Presumably this is a public key, and we check whether the corresponding private key has signed the certificate?  If this returns false, is there any more information we can provide about why, or is it just a mismatch and we know nothing more about it?

In general with crypto verification operations, they either completely succeed or completely fail with no information as to why. It's just the result we calculate is not what's there. No easy way to debug it (by design -- if you could find anything out, it would necessarily give away information about the key and enable attacks).
Is there any reason why this is "parseX" and the others are "forX"?
Mostly because it's actually parsing a string, versus the others which are just using it verbatim in a typed Identity. Do you think `forDN()` would be a better name?
Is it worth either enumerating the possible formats, or referencing the constructor above where they were enumerated?
Any reason this wouldn't just be a VError cause?
sshpk doesn't use VError (and doesn't for the other existing Errors). We could maybe change this, but I think it'd be a separate change in its own right (and require a major bump)
That's fine, though I'd be curious why it would be a major bump.
assert-plus has an assert.date function which you can use here.
Is this alias just so you can evolve the two methods separately if needed?
Yeah. Though upon further reflection, I think it's actually important to start strict about types in the public API

If you're going to modify the options object, perhaps you should make a shallow copy of it, so that a second call with the same options object at a later time doesn't use an earlier Date.

It looks like you don't need to modify options, too. It looks like you can just save the value in a local variable and use that below.
Same thing here. You can just use a local variable to avoid updating the caller's options object.
Would it make sense to lift these into constants like EMAIL_CONTEXT, HOST_CONTEXT, etc., for this switch?

This file has a lot of t.ok()'s without any information. It would be nice if they had names like 'cert is signed by George', 'cert is not signed by Barry', so that assert failures will be easier to find, rather than counting down from the test name.
Is there a reason that this is commented out?
Some information like 'Issuer information in output', 'Subject in output', etc. would be good here.
This file has tests to check that things do verify, but there don't seem to be any to ensure that different signatures of the same type don't.
Should `validFrom` and `validUntil` also be documented here?
